review_title: An excellent environment and educational space in the 90's
pros: In the 90's the AGO was 80% government funded (20% from ticket sales) and was a fantastic place to work with perfect work-life balance and a robust exhibit line-up, engaging public programs that were well attended by all. The previous entrance and interior flow of the gallery was easy to navigate.
cons: Naturally some politics played out however the work experience was superior.

review_title: Great place to work but hours are hard to come by.
pros:
-Professional Staff 
-Good working conditions 
-Good environment 
-Clear duties and responsibilities
 -You will actually get breaks and finish when you are scheduled to (rare in the food industry)
cons:
-Hours are hard to come by until you have seniority
-Occasionally get hit with "the book"

pros: Free access to tourist spots
cons: They only hire part time and you have to wait forever for fulltime positions

pros:
Some of the people are lovely and talented. 
Access to art and events. 
Brand recognition for your CV.
cons:
Terrible management, completely out of touch. An antiquated structure in which departments and individuals are pitted against one another, instead of working together toward a shared mission. Middle management are very good at managing up and hiding their poor behaviour from senior management. It's been going on this way so long it would seem that senior management prefers it this way. 
There is of course a lot of bureaucracy - it's an old, mid-sized institution working with two unions. But it's a lie that this is the main reason why things are so inefficient. It is an ingrained and traditional hierarchy - the inefficiency comes from the top via poor communication, poor organization, bad practices and backwards ideas.
New employees are set up to fail - my "onboarding" basically amounted to "hear is your windowless cube, here are the files, now get to work." I was lucky to be seated next to my very kind former co-worker, who I was forced to ask about 20 questions a day due to the fact that there were no guidelines or resources. It was also like walking back into the 1950s...weird, sad cubicles for lower lever staff and windowed offices for management. I was expected to be at my desk at 9am, regardless of my actual schedule. There was no consideration for wfh, then the pandemic came along and they were screwed...completely unprepared to work in the modern world. It took three months for for them to set me up with a laptop, which I needed since the VPN wasn't working on my personal laptop. Some people never got one! We had team meetings via conference call (I'm serious), until management learned how to navigate zoom. Sadly, it seems they have not learned from these many mistakes as they've announced a mandatory, full-time return to in-office. This is mind-boggling. Amidst a labour shortage they are making themselves an even less-desirable place to work.
Bullying was common and rewarded, an atmosphere of classism and racism simmered under the surface. 

Of course, this is the tip of the iceberg. Ultimately, I understand why people would be drawn to work here, but if you can get your experience somewhere else that actually values its workforce and has some consideration for positive workplace culture and work/life balance - please do.

job_title: Event Sales Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Great benefits
-Good hours
-Good pay if you're local
-Beautiful space in the galleries
-Some nice people
cons:
-Event offices are in a dark, confined basement
-Event staff don't cover their mouth when they sneeze or cough ("we're all breathing the same recycled air anyways)
-Management in Events department is very unprofessional, divulging too much detailed information about their private life and extremely inappropriate on social media
-Unfair in the hiring process - management in the events dept only wants to hire people who are "city people", won't get married/go on maternity leave any time soon, have a 20 minute commute or less, not using a recruiter and not currently unemployed
-Departments are at "war" with one another, lots of gossip and drama
-Events management doesn't listen, explodes and jumps down your throat, refuses to hear you out

review_title: Great place to work - unfortunately closed because of covid.
pros: Fair pay, fair hours, fair working environment. Bonus - all the art your eyes can handle.
cons: All around great, however there was a total psychopath working in my department who was eventually fired, but he made things very stressful.  They also need to actively work on inclusivity training. Not particularly LGBTQ friendly. There were definitely some border line human rights infractions that contravene Ontario labour code, but these things are difficult to fight.

review_title: Toxic Work Environment with Unqualified Leaders
pros: Nice to work at the art gallery.
cons: The leadership is unqualified and creates a toxic workplace.

review_title: Organization held back by stagnant senior leadership
pros: You'll meet some great people, and the place is a good stepping stone to bigger and better things if you're hoping to start a long term career in the arts.
cons:
The current senior management team is long past its "best by" date.  There are occasional infusions of new talent from the business sector, but they learn quickly that there's little actual desire to change (lots of talk, but lots of political pushback), and move on once they figure out there isn't much they can do.
Compensation varies depending on your job; management roles are reasonably well salaried (relative to the non-profit sector), but other areas are made to keep costs down by relying heavily on part timers and low hourly rates.  
HR does a very poor job of orienting and supporting managers, and training is practically non-existent.

job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Toronto, ON
pros: A lot of freedom with how you manage the group of kids (summer camps). Other counselors are ready to take up extra duties whenever one of us is sick. Friendley environment.
cons: Not a lot of training is done beforehand. You hit the ground running. Sometimes I was unsure about the company's policies. The activities for older children, teenagers could be better - you could tell they were bored.
